title: Epidemiology - FQE Feb 2022 | Past Papers
description: KMTC Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Health Records and Information Technology - Epidemiology Paper, February 2022

questions.question: The bills of mortality quantified patterns of diseases and death in the population also analyzed reports of births and deaths were published by?
questions.explanation: Explanation: John Graunt (1620-1674) was a pioneer in vital statistics who analyzed the "Bills of Mortality" in London, quantifying patterns of birth and death.

questions.question: ---- Epidemiology focuses on the determinants of disease by testing hypothesis
questions.explanation: Explanation: Analytic epidemiology is concerned with the "Why" and "How" (determinants) and involves testing hypotheses using comparison groups (e.g., Case-Control, Cohort).

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of descriptive studies?
questions.explanation: Explanation: "Observational" is a broad category that includes both Descriptive and Analytic studies. It is not a specific type of descriptive study like Case reports, Case series, or Cross-sectional surveys.

questions.question: What type of a bias arises when individuals with a particular exposure of adverse outcome is likely to remember their experiences differently from those who are not similarly affected
questions.explanation: Explanation: Recall bias occurs when cases (those with the outcome) remember or report past exposures differently (usually more accurately or with exaggeration) than controls.

questions.question: Which is basic measure of disease frequency in human population?
questions.explanation: Explanation: The simplest/most basic measure is a Count (number of cases). However, for comparing populations, Rates and Proportions are used. In many basic epidemiology contexts, "Count" is the starting point.

questions.question: ---- quantifies the proportion of individuals in a population who have a disease at a specific instance and provides an estimate of the probability that an individual will be ill at a point in time
questions.explanation: Explanation: Prevalence measures the status of disease at a specific point in time ("Do you have the disease now?"). It estimates the probability of currently being ill.

questions.question: Non clinical disease can be classified into the following except
questions.explanation: Explanation: Standard stages of non-clinical disease are Pre-clinical (not yet apparent), Sub-clinical (asymptomatic but detectable), and Latent (hidden/inactive). "Semi-clinical" is not a standard epidemiological term.

questions.question: The number of people at risk in whom a certain illness develops compared to the total number of people at risk is called?
questions.explanation: Explanation: The definition "New cases / Population at risk" is Cumulative Incidence. An Attack Rate is a specific type of cumulative incidence used for outbreaks. Given both options, Cumulative Incidence is the general term, but if the context is an outbreak, Attack Rate applies. However, option A is the formal definition.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a characteristic of a single exposure outbreak?
questions.explanation: Explanation: A single exposure (point source) outbreak typically shows an explosive (sharp/sudden) rise in cases as everyone is exposed at the same time.

options.text: b) Increasing severity with increasing age
d) Cases include both people who have been exposed and those who were not exposed

questions.question: The type of surveillance in which project staff are recruited to carry out is called?
questions.explanation: Explanation: In Active Surveillance, dedicated staff actively visit facilities to find and record cases, rather than waiting for reports.

questions.question: Prevalence can be decreased by the following except
questions.explanation: Explanation: Increased incidence adds more cases to the pool, thereby increasing prevalence. Death, Cure, and Reduced incidence all lower prevalence.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a limitation of hospital data?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Being "Cheap and easy to collect" is an advantage (strength), not a limitation. Options A, C, and D are valid limitations of hospital data.

options.text: b) Cheap and easy to collect
c) They’re not designed for research
d) Population at risk is generally not defined

questions.question: The examining of geographic or spatial differences in incidence can be done in a form of?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Spot maps are used to display the spatial/geographic distribution of disease cases. Time series (B) and Histograms (D) show time or frequency distributions.

questions.question: The relationship between incidence and prevalence is demonstrated through one of the Following
questions.explanation: Explanation: The formula is $P \approx I \times D$ (Prevalence = Incidence × Duration). Duration is a function of Time.

questions.question: Which one of the following is an advantage of active surveillance?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Active surveillance is more accurate/complete because dedicated staff do the work, reducing the burden on clinical providers who might otherwise forget to report. Options A, B, and D are advantages of Passive surveillance.

options.text: b) Is relatively inexpensive to employ
c) More accurate due to reduced reporting burden for health care providers
d) Reporting systems can be developed quickly

questions.question: ------ is the number of individuals dying during a specific period of time after disease onset divided by the number of individuals with the specified disease multiplied by 100
questions.explanation: Explanation: CFR = (Deaths from disease / Cases of disease) × 100. It measures severity/virulence.

questions.question: For a disease like pancreatic cancer, which is highly fatal and of short duration, one of the following statements is true
questions.explanation: Explanation: For highly fatal diseases with short survival, almost everyone who gets it (incidence) dies (mortality). Thus, Incidence ≈ Mortality.

options.text: a) Incidence rates and mortality rates will be similar
b) Mortality rates will be much higher than incidence rates
c) Incidence rates will be much higher that mortality rates
d) Incidences rates will be unrelated to mortality rate

questions.question: The ability of a test to distinguish between those who have a disease and those who do not have a disease is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Validity (Accuracy) is the general ability of a test to measure what it purports to measure (i.e., distinguish diseased from non-diseased). Sensitivity and Specificity are the two components of validity.

questions.question: The variation between those reading the test results is called
questions.explanation: Explanation: Inter-observer variation is the difference in interpretation between two or more different observers/readers.

questions.question: Which one of the following does not happen in clinical phase of a disease?
questions.explanation: Explanation: This is a tricky question. A, C, and D are definitive features of the Clinical Phase. Pathologic evidence (B) exists in the Sub-clinical/Pre-clinical phase as well (before symptoms). Therefore, B is the one that is not exclusive to the clinical phase or happens earlier.

options.text: a) Signs and symptoms of disease
b) Pathologic evidence of disease if sought

questions.question: Which one of the following is not s purpose of randomized clinical trial?
questions.explanation: Explanation: RCTs are for evaluation of efficacy (A, B, C). Planning and allocation (D) rely on descriptive epidemiology (distribution, burden of disease), not clinical trials.

options.text: a) Evaluation of new drugs and treatment
b) Testing of new health and mediocre technology
c) Assess new program for screening
d) Planning of health care services and allocation of resources

questions.question: ------ is an inert substance that looks, tastes and smells like the active agent
questions.explanation: Explanation: A placebo is a dummy treatment used in control groups to blind participants/investigators.

questions.question: In clinical trials, phase two trials consist of how many subjects
questions.explanation: Explanation: - Phase I: 20-80 (Safety). - Phase II: 100-300 (Efficacy). - Phase III: 1000-3000 (Confirmation). - Phase IV: Post-marketing (Thousands).

questions.question: Another term for group matching in case control studies
questions.explanation: Explanation: Frequency matching involves selecting controls so that the proportion of controls with a characteristic (e.g., gender) matches the proportion of cases with that characteristic. Pair matching (B) is individual matching.

questions.question: In -----studies the controls are a sample of individuals who are at risk of the disease at the time each case of the disease develops
questions.explanation: Explanation: A Nested Case-Control study is conducted within a cohort. Controls are selected from those at risk at the time a case occurs (Incidence Density Sampling).

questions.question: Which one of the following is a good estimate of relative risk from case control studies?
questions.explanation: Explanation: In case-control studies (where incidence cannot be calculated), the Odds Ratio is used as an estimate of the Relative Risk (especially for rare diseases).

questions.question: Studies show that approximately 85% of lung cancer cases are due to cigarette smoking. This measure is an example of
questions.explanation: Explanation: This statement describes the proportion of disease attributed to the exposure. This is the definition of Attributable Risk/Fraction.

questions.question: If a factor is believed to be the cause of a disease, exposure to the factor must have occurred before the disease occurrence. This is called?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Temporality (Time) is the essential criterion: Cause must precede Effect.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a type of information bias?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Bias is broadly classified into Selection Bias and Information Bias. Recall (D), Reporting (C), and Surveillance (B) are types of Information Bias. Selection Bias is a separate category.

questions.question: The following terms are used when dealing with evaluation of health services except?
questions.explanation: Explanation: Efficacy, Effectiveness, and Efficiency are the "3 Es" of health service evaluation. Effect modification (Interaction) is an analytical concept in epidemiology, not a service evaluation metric.

questions.question: The characterization of the potential adverse health effects, of human exposure to environmental hazards is referred to as
questions.explanation: Explanation: Risk Assessment is the systematic process of evaluating the potential risks (adverse effects) involved in a projected activity or exposure.

questions.question: In epidemiology, who advocated for careful monitoring when sharing personal information in the interest of societal benefit
questions.explanation: Explanation: William Farr (19th Century) is known as the father of modern vital statistics and surveillance. He recognized the ethical balance between privacy and public good in data collection.

questions.question: For an infectious disease to occur, there must be interaction between
questions.explanation: Explanation: The fundamental interaction for disease occurrence is between the Agent and the Host (usually in an Environment). Vectors are not required for all diseases.

questions.question: THE "BEINGS" model is a useful paradigm for
questions.explanation: Explanation: BEINGS (Biological, Environmental, Immunological, Nutritional, Genetic, Social) describes causes/etiology.

options.text: a) Evaluating etiological factors in disease
b) Assessing the impact of herd immunity
c) Establishing the importance of social contact
d) Allocating of public health resources

questions.question: Which one of the following is mostly used as an overall index of the health status?
questions.explanation: Explanation: IMR is widely regarded as the most sensitive indicator of the overall health status and development of a population.

options.text: b) Cause of specific death rate

questions.question: The outbreak of a disease should be reported to the local or state health department, in what context
questions.explanation: Explanation: Any outbreak (unusual increase) should be reported regardless of the specific disease, as investigation is needed. However, traditionally, "If the disease is infectious" (C) is a trigger, but modern surveillance reports any cluster. "Under all circumstances" covers known and unknown outbreaks.

options.text: a) If the diagnosis is uncertain
c) If the disease is infectious
d) If the disease is serious

questions.question: An official from the state department of public health visits outpatient clinics and emergency rooms to determine the number of cases of post exposure prophylaxis of rabies. The official action is an example of
questions.explanation: Explanation: The official visits the facilities to find data. This is Active Surveillance.

questions.question: ---- must be associated with both exposure and outcome
questions.explanation: Explanation: A confounding variable must be associated with the exposure AND be a risk factor for the outcome (disease).

questions.question: ----- alters the nature of the true relationship between exposure and an outcome
questions.explanation: Explanation: Effect Modification (Interaction) occurs when the magnitude of the effect of an exposure depends on the level of a third variable (the modifier). It alters the nature/strength of the relationship. Confounding (B) distorts/masks the true relationship, while Modification is part of the true nature.

questions.question: A case control study may have a particular advantage over what study when the disease in question is
questions.explanation: Explanation: Case-Control studies are specifically efficient for Rare diseases, where Cohort studies would require impossibly large sample sizes.

questions.question: State three tools used when characterizing an epidemic (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Epidemic Curve: A histogram showing the number of cases over time. Helps determine the type of outbreak (point source vs propagated). Spot Map: A map showing the geographic location of cases to identify clustering. Attack Rate Table (Cross-tabulation): Analysis of cases by person characteristics (age, sex) or exposure (food items) to identify risk groups.

options.text: Epidemic Curve: A histogram showing the number of cases over time. Helps determine the type of outbreak (point source vs propagated).
Spot Map: A map showing the geographic location of cases to identify clustering.
Attack Rate Table (Cross-tabulation): Analysis of cases by person characteristics (age, sex) or exposure (food items) to identify risk groups.

questions.question: Write short notes on vehicle mode of transmission (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Definition: Transmission of disease via a non-living intermediary (vehicle) that conveys the infectious agent from its reservoir to a susceptible host. Examples of Vehicles: Food (Salmonella), Water (Cholera), Biological products (Blood/Serum), Fomites (bedding, surgical instruments). Mechanism: The agent may multiply or develop in the vehicle (e.g., bacteria in food) or simply be carried passively. Control: Sanitation, food safety, sterilization.

options.text: Definition: Transmission of disease via a non-living intermediary (vehicle) that conveys the infectious agent from its reservoir to a susceptible host.
Examples of Vehicles: Food (Salmonella), Water (Cholera), Biological products (Blood/Serum), Fomites (bedding, surgical instruments).
Mechanism: The agent may multiply or develop in the vehicle (e.g., bacteria in food) or simply be carried passively.

questions.question: Epidemiology is usually concerned with health related states/events. Explain (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Epidemiology studies not just "disease" (pathology), but a broad range of health phenomena. Health States: Includes physiological conditions (e.g., blood pressure, pregnancy), mental health, and positive health indicators. Events: Includes injuries, accidents, violence, suicides, and vital events (births, deaths). Behaviors: Includes smoking, diet, physical activity, and use of health services. This broad scope allows epidemiology to address the full spectrum of public health issues.

options.text: Epidemiology studies not just "disease" (pathology), but a broad range of health phenomena.
Health States: Includes physiological conditions (e.g., blood pressure, pregnancy), mental health, and positive health indicators.
Events: Includes injuries, accidents, violence, suicides, and vital events (births, deaths).
Behaviors: Includes smoking, diet, physical activity, and use of health services.
This broad scope allows epidemiology to address the full spectrum of public health issues.

questions.question: Differentiate between Retrospective and Prospective studies (5 marks)
questions.explanation: Feature Retrospective Study Prospective Study Direction Looks backward in time. Looks forward in time. Timing of Events Exposure and Outcome have already occurred at the start of the study. Exposure occurs, then participants are followed to see if Outcome occurs. Examples Case-Control Studies. Cohort Studies. Cost/Time Cheaper and faster. Expensive and time-consuming.

questions.question: Between the year 2019 and 2021, the average annual incidence rate of lung cancer in Country X, was 45.9 per 100,000 and the annual prevalence rate was 23 per 100,000. a) Calculate the average duration of lung cancer (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Formula: $Prevalence \approx Incidence \times Duration$ ($P = I \times D$) Given: Incidence ($I$) = 45.9 per 100,000 per year Prevalence ($P$) = 23 per 100,000 Calculation: $$ 23 = 45.9 \times D $$ $$ D = \frac{23}{45.9} $$ $$ D \approx 0.501 \text{ years} $$ Answer: The average duration is approximately 0.5 years (or 6 months). This suggests lung cancer is highly fatal or cures are very rapid (unlikely for cancer, so it implies high fatality).

questions.question: The population of the city of Atlantis on March 30th 2012 was 183,000. The number of new active cases of TB occurring between January 1st to June 30th, 2012 was 26. Number of active cases TB cases according to the city register on June 30 2012 was 264. i. Calculate the incidence rate of active TB cases for the 6 months' period ii. Calculate the prevalence rate of active TB as of June 2012 (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: i. Incidence Rate (Jan 1 - June 30): Numerator (New Cases) = 26 Denominator (Population) = 183,000 $Rate = \frac{26}{183,000} \times 100,000 = \mathbf{14.2} \text{ per 100,000 per 6 months}$. ii. Prevalence Rate (Point Prevalence, June 30): Numerator (Existing Cases) = 264 Denominator (Population) = 183,000 $Rate = \frac{264}{183,000} \times 100,000 = \mathbf{144.3} \text{ per 100,000}$.

questions.question: In an Asian country with a population of 6 million people, 60,000 deaths occurred during the year ending 31st December 2010. These included 30,000 deaths from cholera in 100,000 people who were sick with cholera required; i. What is the cause specific mortality rate of cholera in 2010 ii. What is the case fatality rate from cholera in 2010 (5 marks)
questions.explanation: i. Cause Specific Mortality Rate (Cholera): Formula: (Deaths from Cause / Total Population) × Multiplier $$ = \frac{30,000}{6,000,000} \times 1,000 $$ $$ = 0.005 \times 1,000 = \mathbf{5} \text{ deaths per 1,000 population} $$ ii. Case Fatality Rate (Cholera): Formula: (Deaths from Disease / Cases of Disease) × 100 $$ = \frac{30,000}{100,000} \times 100 $$ $$ = 0.3 \times 100 = \mathbf{30\%} $$

questions.question: Differentiate between selection and information bias on epidemiological studies (5 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Selection Bias: Occurs during the recruitment/selection of study participants. It happens when the study population does not represent the target population (e.g., Non-response bias, Healthy worker effect). It distorts the relationship between exposure and outcome because of who is in the study. Information Bias (Measurement Bias): Occurs during the data collection phase. It involves systematic errors in measuring exposure or outcome (e.g., Recall bias, Interviewer bias). It distorts the relationship because the data collected is inaccurate.

options.text: Selection Bias: Occurs during the recruitment/selection of study participants. It happens when the study population does not represent the target population (e.g., Non-response bias, Healthy worker effect). It distorts the relationship between exposure and outcome because of who is in the study.

Information Bias (Measurement Bias): Occurs during the data collection phase. It involves systematic errors in measuring exposure or outcome (e.g., Recall bias, Interviewer bias). It distorts the relationship because the data collected is inaccurate.

questions.question: An hypothetical cohort study of 300 cigarette smokers and non-smokers was carried out. 84 smokers developed coronary heart disease while 4913 nonsmokers did not develop coronary heart disease. (Wait, text says "300 cigarette smokers and non-smokers" then gives "4913 non-smokers"? Let's assume the question implies a larger total or the text has a typo. Let's look at the standard version of this question usually found in KMTC papers or calculate based on provided numbers if possible. The text usually implies "3000" or similar. But let's assume the numbers given: 84 smokers sick. 4913 non-smokers WELL. We need totals). Re-reading text from image: "An hypothetical cohort study of 300 cigarette smokers and non-smokers was carried out. 84 smokers developed coronary heart disease while 4913 nonsmokers did not develop coronary heart disease." Correction: The number "300" likely refers to the smokers? Or is it 3000? And "non-smokers" total is missing? Let's assume standard 2x2 table construction is asked. i. Present the above information ha 2x2 table (2 marks) ii. Calculate the incidence of CHD among the smokers (2 marks) iii. Calculate the incidence of CHD among nonsmokers (2 marks) iv. Calculate Relative risk (2 marks) v. Interpreted your relative risk (2 marks)
questions.explanation: Note on Data: The numbers in the prompt seem incomplete or inconsistent (e.g., "300 smokers and non-smokers" vs "4913 non-smokers"). However, usually, in these exams: Let's assume: - Total Smokers = 300 (from the first sentence, assuming "300 smokers"). Cases = 84. - Non-smokers: 4913 did NOT develop. Let's assume total non-smokers = 5000 (common round number) or we need more data. Alternative Interpretation: Maybe "3000" smokers? 84 cases. Let's assume the question meant: Smokers: Total 300. Ill = 84. Well = 216. Non-smokers: Total = 5000. Well = 4913. Ill = 87. This allows calculation. Let's proceed with this assumption to demonstrate the method. i. 2x2 Table: CHD (Yes)No CHD (No)Total Smokers84 (a)216 (b)300 Non-smokers87 (c)4913 (d)5000 ii. Incidence in Smokers ($I_e$): $$ = \frac{84}{300} \times 100 = 28\% $$ iii. Incidence in Non-smokers ($I_u$): $$ = \frac{87}{5000} \times 100 = 1.74\% $$ iv. Relative Risk (RR): $$ RR = \frac{I_e}{I_u} = \frac{28}{1.74} = 16.1 $$ v. Interpretation: Smokers are 16.1 times more likely to develop Coronary Heart Disease than non-smokers. This indicates a very strong positive association between smoking and CHD.

questions.question: Explain 5 methods that are being employed to interrupt the transmission of COVID – 19 In Kenya. (10 marks) (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hand Hygiene: Frequent washing with soap and water or alcohol-based sanitizer to kill the virus on hands (Mode of transmission: Contact). Respiratory Hygiene/Masking: Wearing face masks to contain droplets from infected persons and protect susceptible persons (Mode: Droplet). Social Distancing: Maintaining physical distance (1.5 - 2 meters) to prevent droplet transmission. Vaccination: Administering vaccines (e.g., AstraZeneca, Pfizer) to build herd immunity and reduce susceptibility. Quarantine and Isolation: Isolation: Separating sick (positive) people from healthy ones. Quarantine: Restricting movement of exposed/suspected contacts.

options.text: Hand Hygiene: Frequent washing with soap and water or alcohol-based sanitizer to kill the virus on hands (Mode of transmission: Contact).
Respiratory Hygiene/Masking: Wearing face masks to contain droplets from infected persons and protect susceptible persons (Mode: Droplet).
Social Distancing: Maintaining physical distance (1.5 - 2 meters) to prevent droplet transmission.
Vaccination: Administering vaccines (e.g., AstraZeneca, Pfizer) to build herd immunity and reduce susceptibility.
Quarantine and Isolation: Isolation: Separating sick (positive) people from healthy ones. Quarantine: Restricting movement of exposed/suspected contacts.
Isolation: Separating sick (positive) people from healthy ones.
Quarantine: Restricting movement of exposed/suspected contacts.
